stimulusHtml: A disk is free to rotate about an axle at the disk’s center. A force of magnitude F is exerted tangentially at the edge of the disk, as shown in the left figure, and the disk has angular acceleration α. The disk is returned to rest and a second identical disk is placed on top of the first disk, as shown in the middle figure. The disks move together and do not slip. A force with magnitude F is again exerted tangentially at the edge of the first disk, as shown in the right figure. A student claims that the angular acceleration will again be α when the force of magnitude F is exerted on the two-disk system. Is the claim correct? Why or why not?
choicesHtml: No, because the rotational inertia of the two-disk system is greater than that of the single disk.
No, because the two-disk system has twice the mass as the first disk and will therefore have twice the angular acceleration.
Yes, because the net torque exerted by the force is the same in both cases.
Yes, because the force is exerted at the same distance from the axis in both cases.
